subject: RE: [junit] testing private methods
msgSnippet: ... This problem is definitely not a JUnit problem.  It is just that it would be nice if JUnit could handle this problem (Works Out of The Box[1]). Another
messageBody:
> [...] The smell is in the tension between the
> desired source code layout and the access rules of the
> language. I don't see how JUnit is responsible for this smell,
> or a JUnit-based solution
> (like, say, hacking it to use reflection in order to break access
> control) that doesn't bring along serious code smells of its own.

This problem is definitely not a JUnit problem. It is just that it
would be nice if JUnit could handle this problem (Works Out of The
Box[1]).

Another tension is that of consistency: if you code ALL your test
classes as Inner classes, you may well use them to test private access
methods also. If you don't, however, you add an extra smell and
inconsistent use of Inner/Test classes. This could become a maintenance
problem.

> I rather liked JB Rainsberger's idea that the need to test a private
> method directly suggests refactoring it into a collaborating
> class. I'm not sure it's universally applicable, but i do prefer
> looking for smells in my code rather than my tools.

I also think that extracting some private behaviour into its own class
is a good idea, and a good design decision (at times). It helps in
maintaining coherence: if a method doesn't quite fit, move it to another
class.

And although I also prefer taking the time going through my code, not
through my tools, sometimes I would like to extend my tools with some
features that would help me work even quicker (the reason I have tools
in the first place). This is why we share our thoughts with others, to
see if it does seem like a useful feature (depending on votes in
favour).

[May I add: I actually practice testing public (i.e. non-private)
methods, and do not require the private testing functionality. But I
believe that it should be considered for those who may prefer to code
that way.

OT-- On this note: another topic that props up frequently is that of
parallel source trees. Some readers seem to have difficulties
understanding this concept. Is this mentioned in any of the existing
documentation, and could a link be added on the welcome letter? ]
